title: Leader's Expose
description: Learn what Leader's Expose is, why it good to draft one, how to prepare yours and what to include in it.

published_attributes.title: About the course
published_attributes.serialized_body:
Your team may have some blind spots when it comes to you as a leader - your values, expectations and strengths, to name just a few. The goal of this course is to provide you with a tool to effectively eliminate such blind spots.

In this course you will learn why, what is and how to prepare a Leader's Expose and how it can help you and your team work more efficiently.

blocks.text: Your team may have some blind spots when it comes to you as a leader - your values, expectations and strengths, to name just a few. The goal of this course is to provide you with a tool to effectively eliminate such blind spots.
In this course you will learn why, what is and how to prepare a Leader's Expose and how it can help you and your team work more efficiently.

published_attributes.title: What is Leader's Expose
published_attributes.serialized_body: Leader's Expose or Leader's Readme or My Values document is a document which you as a Leader share and discuss with your Team Members for them to better understand your values, expectations, things you appreciate, things you don't appreciate (or tolerate), what you bring to the table and what is good to know about you, to name a few.

blocks.text: Leader's Expose or Leader's Readme or My Values document is a document which you as a Leader share and discuss with your Team Members for them to better understand your values, expectations, things you appreciate, things you don't appreciate (or tolerate), what you bring to the table and what is good to know about you, to name a few.

blocks.text: Leader's Expose or Leader's Readme or My Values document is a document which you as a Leader share and discuss with your Team Members for them to better understand your values, expectations, things you appreciate, things you don't appreciate (or tolerate), what you bring to the table and what is good to know about you, to name a few.

published_attributes.title: Why Leader's Expose?
published_attributes.serialized_body:
There are a lot of benefits of creating a Leader's Readme and sharing it with the Team. Below are 3 most evident ones:

  1. Give the Team a chance to get to know you better as a Leader. Base the relationship with your Team Members on clear communication, not assumptions.
  2. Set clear expectations and boundaries. If need be you can always refer back to your Leader's Expose.
  3. Work more effectively. The better the Team knows you, the more efficiently they can work. And vice versa.

published_attributes.title: What to include in your Leader's Expose?
published_attributes.serialized_body:
Below are some areas and examples of things which you could include in your Leader's Expose.

Click the +examples buttons in the embedded window below to learn more. When you're finished click the Complete button below.

published_attributes.title: What to include in my Leader's Expose?
published_attributes.serialized_body:
You've just had a chance to go through some examples of areas and things you might want to include in your Leader's Expose. The list of course isn't finite. Below are some more ideas you might take into consideration:

  • fun fact about you
  • the leadership philosophy that you follow
  • your working habits
  • your communication style
  • things people might misunderstand about you
  • your superpowers
  • your Achilles heel
  • random things the team should know about you

published_attributes.title: When to draft and share it with the team?
published_attributes.serialized_body:
As a new Netguru leader there are two possible scenarios:

  1. This is your first leadership experience.
  2. You already have some leadership experience from a previous company or companies.

In case the first one is true, you may want to take some time to figure out what to include in your Leader's Expose. Do some solid self-reflection before going out to your team. Take a couple of months maybe and take it slow.

In the second scenario it may turn out that you have it all figured out and you can draft your Leader's Expose pretty quickly and share it with your team right away.

Whichever is true, do it your way and don't treat this guide as something set in stone :)

published_attributes.title: How to share Leader's Expose with your Team?
published_attributes.serialized_body:
The sky is the limit probably. However if you're hesitating, these are the media we would recommend:

  • Confluence page
  • Google doc/ Google slides
  • Miro board
  • Google Jamboard

When it comes to what comes next when you have your Leader's Expose ready, here is what we recommend:

  1. Share it with each team member individually - give them time to go through it and space to ask you questions, clarify stuff or simply give feedback - you may want to schedule a dedicated call for this purpose or use your regular one-on-one meeting for it.
  2. Encourage each of your team members to prepare their own expose and share it with you. It may include things that they wish to share with you. Find time and space to discuss it just like your Leader's Expose. Don't push them, however, if they don't feel like preparing a document. You may as well discuss it on a dedicated call. If you do manage to engage them in such exercise, this might build bridges between you, help you identify common values or beliefs as well as potential areas where tractions may occur and ways of dealing with them.

published_attributes.title: Assignment
published_attributes.serialized_body:
Assignment:

Book a slot in your calendar, preferably Focus time so that you won't get distracted, to start drafting your Leader's Expose.

Think about what you want to include and how and when you want to share it with your team.

Put discussing your Leader's Expose on the agendas of your one-on-one meetings with your team members and make it happen.

published_attributes.serialized_body: At some point, rather sooner than later, you might consider organizing a dedicated workshop to work on your Team Values. Here's how you can do that and what you can work out with your team:

published_attributes.title: Benchmark resources
published_attributes.serialized_body:
Here are leader's readmes prepared by Netguru leaders that can serve as an inspiration and benchmark:

  • Bartosz Biaek - Design Manager
  • Pola Mikoajczak - User Manual
  • Sebastian Stefaski - User guide to working with me as your leader

One last thing that can help you prepare your own user manual:

  • 12 Manager READMEs from Silicon Valleys Top Tech Companies
